Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Low-Vibration, Cryogen-Free Cryostat Microscope System
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Description:
This Major Research Instrumentation project supports the acquisition of a low-vibration, cryogen-free measurement system at the University of California - Berkeley for studying emerging two-dimensional materials such as graphene and transition metal dichalcogenides. The system enables optical and electrical measurements of materials properties with high precision under large magnetic fields, and offers precise control of charge and novel intrinsic properties of electrons in the two-dimensional materials. The trifecta of magnetic field, electrical contacts, and optical excitation offers new research opportunities for probing the quantum phenomena of these novel materials as well as exploring their optoelectronic applications. In the meanwhile, the system provides a platform for forging new collaborations, student training and workforce development. The research positively impacts society through the development of new atomically-thin materials that revolutionize major areas of computing, electronics and human healthcare.

Technical Description:
The emerging, atomically-thin two-dimensional crystals of graphene and transition metal dichalcogenides offer exciting opportunities to develop novel optoelectronic devices by engineering quantum phenomena at the atomic scale. Owing to their reduced dimensionality, two-dimensional materials process unprecedented properties through their enhanced many-body interactions and quantum confinement. To fully explore two-dimensional materials, researchers must understand the interplay among the electrons, lattice phonons, and excitons in such reduced dimensions. The research enabled by this instrument acquisition spans materials science, physics and device engineering. With a novel combination of magnetic field, electrical contacts, and optical pump of materials at low temperatures, the critical quantum behaviors and transport properties of two-dimensional materials can be revealed, which is the key to developing future optoelectronic devices such as valley light-emitting diode, wearable piezoelectric generator, and ultrathin optical sensors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: Building upon the collaboration amongst groups of complementary expertise (Ziqiang Qiu, Michael Crommie, Junqiao Wu, Jie Yao and X. Zhang from University of California, Berkeley), the research was devoted to support the acquisition of an AttoDry2100 low-vibration, cryogen-free measurement system at the University of California - Berkeley for studying emerging two-dimensional (2D) materials such as graphene, transition metal dichalcogenides (TMD) and ferromagnetic chromium triiodide (CrI3). It successfully resulted in the development of innovative platforms for the characterization and the design of 2D structures and materials bestowed with new properties.

Intellectual Merit: The proposed Attocube low-vibration cryogen-free measurement system (Attocube microscope) will enable the optical and electrical probing of properties in the 2D materials with high precision under large magnetic fields. The system offers precise control over all the three degrees of freedom in 2D materials: the electron’s charge, spin, and momenta “valley”. The system’s low vibration and integrated high speed camera provide necessary spatial and temporal resolution to excite and characterize these ultrathin materials. The instrument also provides a unique platform for experiments under extreme conditions such as low temperature (down to 1.6 K) and high magnetic field (up to 9 T). The unique trifecta of magnetic field, electrical contacts, and optical pump in the vacuum, low temperature and high magnetic field will offer new research opportunities for probing the quantum phenomena as well as optoelectronic applications.

Major Activities: The system has been successfully installed recently and a full testing and calibration process have been finished. Multiple optical and electrical setups have been built and integrated with the AttoDry2100 system. For example, magneto-optical measurements (MOKE [Magneto-optical Kerr effect] and MCD [magnetic circular dichroism]), optical measurements (photoluminescence [PL] and Raman), and magneto-transport measurements. A new piezoelectric scanner and an associated module for high precision spatial mapping were installed and tested. Currently there are six regular users (including two superusers) trained for the instrument. The system has also been toured and introduced to the undergraduate and educational outreach students. The research on low-dimensional materials and their heterostructures is actively under investigation with two research papers been already published in high impact journals such as Nature 2019, PNAS 2019.

Broader Impacts: The outcomes of this project result from a balanced synergy between the different teams involved. The formation of undergraduate and graduate students was central in this project, and postdoc were largely involved into this educational aspect. Last, to ensure the sustainability of the project and its continuity, we have now integrated the electric and optical measurement accesses to the system, which will further facilitate new discoveries and new applications for physics and materials science. With this unique instrumentation, the project provides a global leadership at both physics and materials research frontier, as well as offers a collaborative platform among team members and other Berkeley researchers, and will help the US maintain its global leadership in low-dimensional materials research.
